Most people are not familiar with the gravitational energy density. I only happened on it back in the 1970's after I met Joe Weber. He told me to look at his student, Robert Forward's, work. It is g^2/(8 pi G) in SI units, where g is in (meters/second^2), and G is 6.6743E-11 (meters/second^2) per (kilogram/meter^2). At the surface of the earth the gravitational energy density is the same as a magnetic field of about 380 Tesla, a laser of 1.7E19 Watts/m^2 or a black body at 2.95 million Kelvin (not sure if this to within a factor 2 based on different model assumptions). My point is that space is not empty by any means. Even if you do not fill it with gravitons and axions, the gravitational potential itself is extremely stable and well understood. At least color that in 3D so people can see it. And you will see that the earth's gravitational potential is dwarfed by the sun.


The gravitational potential changes constantly because of changes in the atmosphere, oceans, and earth on the earth, and changes on the sun and moon and more distant sources of gravitational potential change. I would like to propose a dark matter candidate not mentioned in this presentation. The dark matter candidate is neutron groups. A neutron group is a group of two or more neutrons which are bonded together and can be described as an atomic nucleus without the protons and of course no orbital electrons. Such neutron groups would be stable just as neutrons in an atomic nucleus are stable.

A single independent neutron will decay into a proton and an electron with a mean lifetime before decay of around 15 minutes. A neutron group does not decay just as a neutron in a nucleus does not normally decay.A neutron group would be invisible an unaffected by light.
More about the formation of neutron groups here:

https://www.academia.edu/5009126/The_evolution_of_the_universe

Richard Lewis The Evolution of the Universe

Looking for dark matter particle candidates produced at the Large Hadron Collider.
While no dark matter candidates have yet been found, their properties -- massive and weakly interacting -- are not unique to undiscovered exotic matter. In fact, particles currently described by the Standard Model of Particle Physics, called "neutrinos", are both massive and weakly interacting. (However, neutrinos are ruled out as functioning dark matter that we observe in the cosmos -- not massive enough.) We even search for dark matter in our detector the same way we measure neutrinos.

"The only explanation is there must be dark material contributing to the gravity"
That's actually not the "ONLY" explanation. An alternative is that we don't actually understand gravity that well and our equations are off. Newton's equations worked fine for basic motion for a long time. It wasn't until we started to deal with high speed physics that we needed more accurate equations, and along came Einstein who's equations allow for a more accurate prediction of how things move.

Just like the flaws in newton's equations don't start to show up until you move to the extremes in terms of movement, so too might the flaws in our equations regarding gravity only show up when view them on the extreme scale of galaxies. After all when you need to create an unknown force that adds about 95% of the overall effect on a model in order to get that model to match what you see in the real world. Odds are pretty good your model has a massive flaw as in pretty much any other field it's on par with saying "god" or "a wizard" is using magic to hold it all together.

Because invisible material that is like nothing found on Earth and is invisible/undetectable but has a huge impact on what we see in the sky is the EXACT SAME thing that people use to claim when trying to justify what causes the planets to move oddly in the sky while the Earth was the Center of the Universe. Just as most see their excuse as crazy and idiotic, so too do I think people will one day look back at "Dark Matter" theories.

Phil,

Suppose, the original evenly distributed dark matter gravitationally coalesced to clumps, to further attract normal matter.
But if DM particles would not interact, the would not lose their extra kinematic energy, and just flew away. Gravitational aggregation always requires some mechanism to dissipate extra kinematic energy, like interaction of dark matter with itself or with normal matter. When normal gas coalesces to a star, the extra kinematic energy of its molecules breaks into chaotic (thermal) motion because the molecules collide with each other. If dark matter particles do not exhibit scattering, they would just fly back into space.

Are there any scientific papers that estimate such interaction and cooling of DM? Are there differences in DM distribution in old and young galaxies and clusters that could be used to estimate cooling of DM?
